awd_titl_txt: Online Competency-Based Education of Technicians in Computer-aided Design and Cyber Security
awd_abstract_narration:
Providing high-quality college education and professional opportunities in rural areas continue to be a national challenge. To help address this challenge, Texas State Technical College will develop and implement on-line competency-based programs in Computer Aided Design and in Cyber Security.  The project will focus on serving non-traditional students and individuals living in rural areas, populations that have less access to technical education programs.  Project activities will include updating and expanding existing curricula to respond to current industry demands; providing professional development for faculty; providing on-going mentoring and support services for students; developing handbooks for faculty who are teaching the courses; developing a model for on-line competency-based education that can be used in other career and technical fields and by other institutions; and supporting job placement opportunities for graduates. This project will also reach high school students through dual enrollment and, thus, has the potential to increase the number of students seeking academic and career opportunities in Computer Aided Design and Cyber Security across Texas. 

Beyond creating and implementing the new curricula, the project is designed to increase connections between students, faculty, the college, and industry.  Such connections have the potential to enhance students' educational experiences, expand the capacity of faculty to understand industry needs and opportunities, and increase the placement of highly qualified technicians into high demand fields.  Program evaluation activities will assess the curriculum development processes, the success of new industry advisory boards, the retention and academic performance of the students, and rates of graduation and placement into industry jobs.  Project results will be presented at academic and professional conferences and submitted for publication. This project is funded by the NSF Advanced Technological Education program that focuses on the education of technicians for the advanced-technology fields that drive the nation's economy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report
NSF Award ID: 1901776 
Organization:  Texas State Technical College (TSTC)
PI: Norma Colunga-Hernandez
Reporting Time Period:  10/01/2021 to 09/30/2022
Award Title: Online Competency-Based Education (CBE) of Technicians in Computer-aided Design and Cybersecurity

The Texas State Technical College (TSTC) System is a coeducational two-year institution of higher education offering courses of study in technical vocational education for which there is demand within the state of Texas. TSTC's mission is to "contribute to the educational and economic development of the state of Texas by offering occupationally oriented programs, with supporting academic coursework, emphasizing highly specialized advanced and emerging technical and vocational areas for certificates or associate degrees" (Vernon's Texas Education Code, Section 135). Unique to TSTC is a results-oriented job placement model that rewards TSTC based on graduate job placement and earned wages, a departure from traditional student contact hours.To align with this innovative results-driven funding formula, TSTC curriculum is driven from a student job placement standpoint.

The Online CBE of Technicians in Computer-aided Design/Architectural Drafting and Engineering Graphics (ADEG) and Cybersecurity (CYS) Project contributes to the next level of performance at TSTC, with a transition to a statewide competency-based model for all program disciplines delivery. The project expands technical career opportunities for students by (1) improving job placement with competency-based, work-ready job skills; (2) providing online course delivery for nontraditional and rural students. It is anticipated that this project will serve as a model for CBE based on the ADEG/CYS programs, not only for online instructional delivery across TSTC, but as a model  that can be adopted and adapted to suit multiple disciplines at other institutions. TSTC has defined its CBE initiative as Performance Based Education (PBE). 

Key to a PBE implementation is the quality and accessibility of curriculum materials and resources provided for student learning, student support, and the strength of the assessments used to measure mastery of skills and competencies. 

The most significant change to PBE from the existing traditional curriculum is the move to individualized, student-centric, self-directed, competency-based learning experiences, with opportunities to accelerate or spend more time on tasks to achieve competency mastery. To accommodate this new modality, curriculum revisions included course deconstruction by competency, development of new learning journey artifacts (lessons, labs, videos, etc.), standardized online course templates, revised processes and policies, quality control, continuous improvement, and associated faculty/staff training. To facilitate execution of PBE hands-on competency-based labs for some TSTC programs, an investment in online remote access space, and facility and equipment reconfigurations and upgrades for hybrid-PBE offerings, was required. 

Enrollment coaches and PBE mentors have been introduced to support student progression through the program, assisting with student registration, retention, advising, and individualized mentoring. Tutoring, instructor-facilitated virtual lab sessions, and messaging applications have been implemented to facilitate faculty-student engagement. Virtual "lab" sessions unify and mirror classroom environments for student and faculty real-time communication and provide opportunities for open discussions and collaboration. 

The mastery assessment is the core component of PBE, validating a student's competency with work-based skills/tasks that prepare students for today's workforce. To identify skills gaps between program curriculum and industry competencies, TSTC partnered with Skills Engine (www.skillsengine.com), using its Calibrate platform for identifying specific job profiles and the associated competencies and work skills. Industry-related employers, including program advisory board members validate and rate the (competencies) for each job profile. To further validate competencies and the curriculum's authenticity, TSTC engaged the Workforce Talent Educators Association (WTEA) (www.workforcetalent.org) for a Career Impact Audit that reviews the strength of assessments used to measure mastery of skill/competency attainment. The review includes three focus areas: (1) Curriculum Alignment based on defined job profiles; (2) Assessment System Strength; (3) Individual Assessment Strength (Task and Context Authenticity, Rigor, Reliability). The Cybersecurity program was the first to undergo this process in Fall 2022, using the feedback received to validate and improve the curriculum and its workforce relevance. Other program disciplines will follow. 

TSTC has institutionalized PBE, with seven programs launched in Fall 2021, to include CYS. Other programs, including ADEG, transitioned in Fall 2022. Additional program disciplines will transition in 2023 and beyond. TSTC's PBE Online College enrollment of part-time and dual enrollment students has increased across the state. Along with the traditional AAS Awards, curriculum based on competency-based modules has facilitated the development of stackable awards (Certificates, Occupational Skills Awards (OSA), micro-credentials, non-credit courses) expanding opportunities for dual enrollment students to earn a certificate, customized workforce training, and the development of job-specific reskilling and upskilling opportunities for those seeking to train on new emerging technologies, or a change in careers. The Texas A&M Engineering Experiment Station (TEES) has partnered with TSTC for an A&M Bachelor's+ program that provides engineering students hands-on applied work experience/skills through OSAs in ADEG, CYS, and five other program disciplines.


Last Modified: 11/29/2022
Modified by: Norma Colunga-Hernandez
